description: Episode number 1 of Series "Treasures from the American Film Archives: 50 preserved films (DVD)". For decades archives have worked behind the scenes to save America's film heritage. Now for the first time, eighteen of the nation's premier archives join forces to showcase the range of films that survive today thanks to their efforts. This disk contains the following titles: "The Original movie" (1922), 8 mins; early films from the Edison Company 3 mins - "Blacksmithing scene" (1893), "The Gay shoe clerk" (1903), "Three American beauties" (1906); "Princess Nicotine or, The Smoke fairy" (1909), 5 mins; "The Confederate ironclad" (1912), 16 mins; "Hells hinges" (1916), 64 mins; "The Fall of the house of Usher" (1928), 13 mins; "From Groucho Marx's home movies" (ca. 1933), 2 mins; From "Tevye" (1939), 17 mins; "Cologne: from the diary of Ray and Esther" (1939), 14 mins; Private Snafu: "Spies" (1943), 4 mins; "OffOn" (1968), 9 mins. Essays about the archives narrated by Laurence Fishburne. Newly recorded musical scores by Martin Marks. Further Information: http://www.filmpreservation.org/
